text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits a revision to IRM 25.5.7, Summons, Special Procedures for John Doe Summonses.

IRM 25.5.7.1 added to include IRM Internal Control Components as required by IRM 1.11.2, Internal Management Document System, Internal Revenue Manuel (IRM) Process. The inclusion of IRM Internal Control Components affects the numbering of subsequent sections within this IRM.
IRM 25.5.7.2, Deﬁnition was removed. This information has been incorporated into IRM 25.5.7.1.1,

IRM 25.5.7.2(2) updated to clarify that a written report is submitted to Area or Associate Area Counsel to request pre-issuance approval of a John Doe summons. Updates also stress the importance of Counsel’s role in the John Doe summons process and references are added to IRC 7609(f) and to the Civil Enforcement Advice & Support Operations (CEASO) organization.

IRM 25.5.7.2(3) added instructions to obtain guidance from Area or Associate Area Counsel when preparing a John Doe summons and to provide additional information about Counsel’s role in the John Doe summons process. This section also clariﬁes that a Form 2039, Summons, is used in the John Doe summons process.
IRM 25.5.7.3.1 changed to reﬂect the current delegation authority to issue a John Doe summons, pursuant to Delegation Order 25-1.
25.5.7.4.2(6) updated to provide more recent dates in the case examples.

) The Summons Handbook provides guidelines for all Internal Revenue (IRS) functions in one multifunctional handbook. (
) Purpose: This IRM provides instructional procedures related to John Doe summonses. (
) Audience: All employees conducting investigations that are beneﬁted by the issuance of John Doe summonses. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Collection Policy, SBSE. (
) Program Owner: Collection Policy, SBSE, Enforcement. (
) Primary Stakeholders: The primary stakeholders include Counsel, Examination and Criminal Investigation, (CI). (

) Program Goals: When an investigation requires information pertaining to activities of an unidentiﬁed person or an ascertainable group or class of persons, a “John Doe” summons may be useful. By following this IRM, employees will understand the appropriate use of the John Doe summons, the legal and procedural requirements for such summons issuance. (

) There are times when the IRS must investigate violations, or potential viola- tions, of internal revenue law by a person, group or class of persons without identifying a speciﬁc individual. A John Doe summons is a summons that not identify the person with respect to whose liability the summons is issued. The Internal Revenue Code authorizes the IRS to issue a John Doe pursuant to an investigation of a speciﬁc, unidentiﬁed person or an able group or class of persons. See IRC

) With a normal summons, the IRS seeks information about a speciﬁc whose identity is known. In contrast, a John Doe summons allows the IRS to obtain the names, requested information and documents concerning all taxpayers in a certain group. A John Doe summons can be a useful tool trying to obtain information like a list of investors in a certain tax shelter, owners of tax-exempt bonds, or account holders at a ﬁnancial institution. (

) and IRC
(f) provide the IRS with John Doe summons authority. (

In general, the IRS issues summonses only when the taxpayer (or other witness) will not produce the desired records or other information voluntarily. In contrast, a John Doe summons is issued to investigate violations or potential violations of internal revenue law when the speciﬁc individuals are not known. John Doe summonses require US District Court approval, therefore reports associated with these cases are maintained by the Office of Chief Counsel.
IRS Counsel maintains procedures regarding US District Court matters in Chief Counsel Directives Manual, CCDM 34.1, Jurisdiction of the District Courts.

) A John Doe summons can only be served after approval by a US District Court. Therefore, the IRS must never serve a “friendly” John Doe summons even though a prospective summoned party may request one as a condition providing information to the IRS. See IRM
), Service of Summons, for a deﬁnition of “friendly summons.” Serving a John Doe summons without court approval violates the statute and will jeopardize the investigation. (

) Submit a written request for pre-issuance approval of a John Doe summons Area or Associate Area Counsel, as appropriate. The summons request state the pertinent facts and circumstances that justify seeking court to serve the summons and include information to satisfy each of the requirements contained in IRC

(f) . Work closely with Area or Associate Area Counsel on a John Doe summons request. It is important to obtain Counsel’s input and assistance to develop a successful John Doe In the rare event a John Doe summons would involve Collection, the for a John Doe summons should be routed through CEASO before sending Associate Area Counsel for ﬁnal review and approval. (
) Discuss the wording to be used in the John Doe summons with Area or Associate Area Counsel. Use Form

, Summons, and provide a draft to Counsel with the pre-issuance request. Area or Associate Area Counsel work with the examiner to perfect the summons, the request and any other documentation needed to support issuance of the summons. Once Counsel will forward the John Doe summons request for approval. (
) Area or Associate Area Counsel will prepare a referral letter on behalf of Counsel to DOJ containing the law and facts justifying court approval. This Internal Revenue Manual

Area or Associate Area Counsel will prepare a referral letter on behalf of Chief Counsel to DOJ containing the law and facts justifying court approval. This
referral letter and proposed summons will be submitted by Associate Area Counsel to Associate Chief Counsel (Procedure & Administration) for its and approval per CCDM
)c, Referrals through the Office of the sociate Chief Counsel (Procedure & Administration). (

) If Associate Area Counsel decides not to forward the matter to Associate Counsel (Procedure & Administration) for referral to the DOJ to seek for service, the matter should be discussed with the Field and CEASO Managers. (
) If an agreement cannot be reached, Counsel will prepare and forward a memorandum to the Area Director setting forth the unresolved issues. (

) If the Area Director does not agree with Counsel’s conclusions, the matter be referred to the Director, Field Operations (CI or LB&I), or the Director, or Collection, or Director, Compliance, (W&I), who will explore with the Associate Chief Counsel, (Procedure & Administration), ways of reaching agreement on future actions concerning the John Doe summons. (

) John Doe summonses are an important investigative tool. To be used tively, extensive coordination is needed with local Counsel and the DOJ. Coordination at each level of the process ensures compliance with the Revenue Code and ensures nothing will jeopardize the investigation. (
) The following paragraphs provide basic background information about Doe summonses. (
) A John Doe summons can only be issued by high ranking individuals who speciﬁcally authorized to do so in Delegation Order No.
Special Authority To revenue agents and revenue officers are not authorized to issue these Doe summonses. When considering a John Doe summons, consult IRM
, vicewide Delegations of Authority, Delegation Order

) The purpose of a John Doe summons must be to investigate the tax a speciﬁc unidentiﬁed taxpayer, (or a group of such taxpayers), even if a Purpose secondary purpose is to gather information for research purposes. (

) The IRS should no longer be in the information-gathering or research a project when it decides to seek court authorization to serve a John Doe summons. The project research should be sufficiently developed to enable IRS to identify a speciﬁc tax compliance problem. The IRS should be to investigate the tax liabilities of speciﬁc taxpayers based on the received from the John Doe summons. A John Doe summons cannot be to conduct a “ﬁshing expedition.” See IRM
, Statutory For a Valid John Doe Summons. (

) A dual-purpose summons is a summons issued with the purposes of gating both the tax liability of a named taxpayer and the tax liability of Summons unnamed parties. In some investigations, it may be possible for the IRS to obtain the identities of taxpayers without issuing a John Doe summons. If IRS is conducting an investigation of a known taxpayer, (such as a tax promoter), who can identify an unknown taxpayer or class of taxpayers, as the shelter investors), and the identities of the unknown taxpayers are Internal Revenue Manual Cat. If an agreement cannot be reached, Counsel will prepare and forward memorandum to the Area Director setting forth the unresolved issues.
A dual
purpose summons is a summons issued with the purposes of investi

gating both the tax liability of a named taxpayer and the tax liability of other, unnamed parties. In some investigations, it may be possible for the IRS to obtain the identities of taxpayers without issuing a John Doe summons. If the IRS is conducting an investigation of a known taxpayer, (such as a tax shelter promoter), who can identify an unknown taxpayer or class of taxpayers, (such as the shelter investors), and the identities of the unknown taxpayers are

The IRS can require the production of the identities of the taxpayers. This technique is only acceptable where discovering the identities the unknown taxpayers is relevant to the investigation of the known dual-purpose summons should be considered before issuance of a John summons. ) The enforcement of a John Doe summons is essentially the same as other summonses as discussed in IRM

, Enforcement of Summons. of a John a John Doe summons has already been referred to DOJ and approved by a US District Court prior to issuance. Therefore, in the event that a John Doe summons requires enforcement, contact Area or Associate Area Counsel for guidance. (

) US District Court Approval Required Before Serving a John Doe Summons. Before a John Doe summons can be served, it must be approved for by a US District Court in an ex parte proceeding. The IRS can never serve John Doe “friendly” John Doe summons without obtaining court approval. Doing so will violate IRC
and jeopardize the investigation. (
) Three Additional Requirements for Approval. A John Doe summons must the standard four-part test that applies to all other summonses. See IRM
, Limitations on Authority to Summon. IRC
(f) adds three addi- tional requirements that a John Doe summons must meet before it will (

for US District Court approval. These three requirements are identiﬁed below and further analyzed in following subsections:

a. The summons must relate to the investigation of a particular person or ascertainable group or class of persons. b. The IRS must have a reasonable basis for believing that such person group or class of persons may fail or may have failed to comply with any provision of the tax laws. c. The information and identities sought to be obtained from summoned records must not be readily available from other sources. (
) Section
of the Taxpayer First Act, PL
, amended IRC
(f) to add ﬂush language consistent with the legislative history to IRC

that a John Doe summons should not be used for a “ﬁshing expedition.” The new ﬂush language states that information sought must be narrowly tailored to in- formation that pertains to the failure, or potential failure, of the unidentiﬁed person, group or class of persons under investigation to comply with one or more provisions of the internal revenue law. This ﬂush language is not an expressed additional requirement for a John Doe summons, but a condition that applies to the three requirements for a John Doe summons. Discuss with Area or Associate Area Counsel the wording to be used in the summons to ensure all requirements are met. (

) The unidentiﬁed person, group or class of persons under investigation, and activity or transaction under investigation must be described with particularity on the line of the summons that begins with “In the matter of.” The phrase “group or class” refers to a group or class of persons who have engaged in speciﬁcally described transactions or activities that are common to all persons or entities in the group or class. Generally, the common activities or transac- tions of the group or class of persons will directly relate to compliance with internal revenue laws. (
) Examples.

The information and identities sought to be obtained from summoned records must not be readily available from other sources.

) The unidentiﬁed person, group or class of persons under investigation, and the activity or transaction under investigation must be described with particularity on the line of the summons that begins with “In the matter of.” The phrase “group or class” refers to a group or class of persons who have engaged in speciﬁcally described transactions or activities that are common to all persons or entities in the group or class. Generally, the common activities or transac- tions of the group or class of persons will directly relate to compliance with the internal revenue laws.
Procedures for John Doe Summonses 25.5.7

A summons is issued to a bank to obtain the names of bondholders who purchased bonds issued by a county’s housing authority for a speciﬁc construction project. The summons should read: “In the matter of the record and beneﬁcial owners of County Housing Authority Revenue Bonds, Series
(Blackacre Housing Project).”
A summons is issued to Dealer X to obtain the names of persons who sold metal to the dealer for the period January
through December
The summons should read: “In the matter of persons who sold metal to Dealer X during the period from January
through December
A summons is issued to ABC University to obtain the names of persons who made in-kind contri- butions to the university during the period January
through December
The summons should read: “In the matter of all persons who made in-kind contributions to ABC Univer- sity for the period January
through December
A summons is issued to Bank XY of Pine County to obtain the names of those taxpayers who transferred funds to the Bank of ABC Islands during the period January
through December

The Bank XY of Pine County is a US clearing bank that handles outbound transfers. The summons should read: “In the matter of the Tax Liabilities of John Does, United States taxpayers who, at any time during the period of January
through December
, transferred funds to the Bank of ABC Islands through Bank XY of Pine County.”
A summons is issued to the XYZ Barter Exchange to obtain the names and transaction records of all members of the exchange for the period of January
through December
The summons should read: “In the matter of all members of the XYZ Barter Exchange during the period of January
through December

A summons is issued to ABC University to obtain the names of persons who made in-kind contri- butions to the university during the period January 1, 2018 through December 31, 2019. The summons should read: “In the matter of all persons who made in-kind contributions to ABC Univer-

A summons is issued to Bank XY of Pine County to obtain the names of those taxpayers who transferred funds to the Bank of ABC Islands during the period January 1, 2017 through 31, 2018. The Bank XY of Pine County is a US clearing bank that handles outbound transfers. summons should read: “In the matter of the Tax Liabilities of John Does, United States taxpayers who, at any time during the period of January 1, 2017 through December 31, 2018, transferred

) The IRS must establish a reasonable basis for suspecting noncompliance with the tax laws by the unidentiﬁed person or the group or class of unidentiﬁed persons that are the subject of the investigation. The IRS need not establish probable cause for suspecting noncompliance or meet any other evidentiary standard greater than a reasonable basis for suspecting noncompliance. The IRS can establish per IRC
) that it has reasonable basis for believing that an individual or a group or class may have or will fail to comply with the
a. The unidentiﬁed person or group has engaged in or is engaging in a transaction or transactions that the IRS has determined to be noncompli
ant with the tax laws, or b. The unidentiﬁed person or group has engaged in or is engaging in an activity or course of actions that is of such a nature that there is a likeli

hood of underreporting or other type of noncompliance with the tax laws. Common Financial Transaction or Activity Related to Tax Law Compliance. A John Doe summons will usually not be appropriate unless the unidentiﬁed group or class of persons has engaged in a common ﬁnancial transaction or an activity directly related to compliance with the tax laws. For example, a group that participates in ﬁnancial activities not susceptible to detection, or designed to avoid detection, or to defeat the payment of taxes may be a candidate for a John Doe summons. On the other hand, members of a group whose only common characteristics relate to non

tax factors, such as political or ideological beliefs, or memberships in trade or professional organizations, should not normally be the subject of a John Doe investigation. Statistical Data Needed as Evidence. To determine whether there is a high degree of noncompliance, the IRS should attempt to investigate or canvass as
a. The unidentiﬁed person or group has engaged in or is engaging in a transaction or transactions that the IRS has determined to be noncompli
ant with the tax laws, or b. The unidentiﬁed person or group has engaged in or is engaging in an activity or course of actions that is of such a nature that there is a likeli
hood of underreporting or other type of noncompliance with the tax laws.
Statistical Data Needed as Evidence. To determine whether there is a high degree of noncompliance, the IRS should attempt to investigate or canvass

many of the group members that it can identify before considering a John Doe summons. The information gathered from these investigations or compliance checks will support the Government’s position that a reasonable basis exists believe that the group or class of persons may have failed to comply with the tax laws. Information or statistical data from investigations of group members from other parts of the country may be used to support a John Doe summons issued to investigate members in a particular area. (

) Statistical Data Not Needed as Evidence. While canvassing or performing compliance checks on the identiﬁed members of a group is generally useful in any John Doe summons case, there may be situations where, in the exercise of sound judgment, such steps can be deemed unnecessary. For example, where the IRS is investigating the promotion of a particular ﬁnancial transac- tion and the promoters have taken a position in the prospectus or other document that is contrary to the IRS’s announced position, it is not necessary to canvass the identiﬁed members to learn whether they did in fact follow the promoters’ tax advice. The reasonable basis standard is met by the promoters’ documents. Also, for example, if a person or persons deposit a large amount of high denomination currency in decrepit condition within a period of a few weeks, the IRS need not try to obtain more factual background on the ﬁed person or persons. The inherently suspicious nature of the deposits meets the reasonable basis standard and makes appropriate a John Doe summons directed to the bank where the deposits took place. (

) Statistical Evidence Needed Where a Common Financial Transaction is Absent. If the IRS has not discovered a common ﬁnancial transaction suggest- ing noncompliance with tax laws in a group or class of persons, a John Doe summons may still be appropriate if investigations of known taxpayers in the group produce a signiﬁcant statistical sample showing a very compelling degree of noncompliance. (A statistical sample that shows
percent or more of noncompliance indicates a high degree of noncompliance. While this is not intended as a bright-line test, to the extent the percentage is less than

percent, it will become more difficult to argue that a reasonable basis exists, and Area Counsel should consider whether a John Doe summons is appropri- ate). A John Doe summons should not be considered where a common ﬁnancial transaction suggesting noncompliance does not exist unless the IRS has ﬁrst gathered statistical data from identiﬁed group members establishing a factual basis for issuing the summons. (

Special Procedures for John Doe Summonses 25.5.7
Continuation of scenario in Example
in IRM

), Ascertainable Group or Class of Persons: The IRS seeks the US District Court’s authorization to serve a John Doe summons on a bank to obtain the names of those persons who purchased bonds issued by a county’s housing authority for a certain construction project. Speciﬁcally, the summons seeks the names of the record and beneﬁcial owners of the bondholders of the County Housing Authority Revenue Bonds, Series
(Blackacre Housing Project).

Persons: The IRS seeks the US District Court’s authorization to serve a John Doe summons on a bank to obtain the names of those persons who purchased bonds issued by a county’s housing authority for a certain construction project. Speciﬁcally, the summons seeks the names of the record and beneﬁcial owners of the bondholders of the County Housing Authority Revenue Bonds, Series

(Blackacre Housing Project). The IRS can satisfy the reasonable basis standard with the following fact pattern. The IRS has learned that the county did not use the bond proceeds to build the advertised housing project. Instead, the proceeds were used to acquire higher yielding investments that generated taxable interest income to the bondholders. The prospectus or other public documents show that the bonds were advertised as tax-exempt municipal bonds. Thus, the unidentiﬁed bondholders have engaged in a transaction based on a promoter’s position that the IRS has rejected. This is enough to establish a reasonable basis for believing that an ascertainable group, the purchasers of County Housing Authority Revenue Bonds, Series

, (Blackacre Housing Project), engaged in a trans- action that is not in compliance with the tax laws, (the non-reporting of taxable interest income). While statistical data gathered from identiﬁed group members may be helpful, it is not necessary to establish a reasonable basis in this case, because the IRS has rejected the promoter’s position.
Continuation of scenario in Example
in IRM

), Ascertainable Group or Class of Persons: The IRS seeks the US District Court’s authorization to serve a John Doe summons on Dealer X, a metal buyer, to obtain the names of persons who sold metal to him during the period January
through December
The IRS can satisfy the reasonable basis standard with the following fact pattern. Metal dealers are not required to issue Forms
to the persons from whom they purchase metal, (the metal suppliers). As a result, the IRS cannot readily detect metal suppliers that underreport income from these sales. Investigations of
metal suppliers who sold metal to Dealer X in prior taxable years showed that
had underreported their income. Also, the IRS has gathered statistical evidence from investigations of other dealers, which shows a high degree of underreporting by the metal suppliers.

learned that the county did not use the bond proceeds to build the advertised housing project. Instead, the proceeds were used to acquire higher yielding investments that generated taxable interest income to the bondholders. The prospectus or other public documents show that the bonds were advertised as tax-exempt municipal bonds. Thus, the unidentiﬁed bondholders have engaged in a transaction based on a promoter’s position that the IRS has rejected. This is enough to establish a reasonable basis for believing that an ascertainable group, the purchasers of County Housing Authority Revenue Bonds, Series 2017, (Blackacre Housing Project), engaged in a trans- action that is not in compliance with the tax laws, (the non-reporting of taxable interest income). While statistical data gathered from identiﬁed group members may be helpful, it is not necessary to establish a reasonable basis in this case, because the IRS has rejected the promoter’s position. Continuation of scenario in Example 2 in IRM 25.5.7.4.1(2) 2), Ascertainable Group or Class of Persons: The IRS seeks the US District Court’s authorization to serve a John Doe summons on Dealer X, a metal buyer, to obtain the names of persons who sold metal to him during the period January 1, 2018 through December 31, 2018. The IRS can satisfy the reasonable basis standard with the following fact pattern. Metal dealers are not required to issue Forms 1099 to the persons from whom they purchase metal, (the metal suppliers). As a result, the IRS cannot readily detect metal suppliers that underreport income from these sales. Investigations of 40 metal suppliers who sold metal to Dealer X in prior taxable years showed that 30 had underreported their income. Also, the IRS has gathered statistical evidence from investigations of other dealers, which shows a high degree of underreporting by the metal suppliers.
John Doe summons is appropriate because the common activity of the group members, (sales metal to Dealer X), is not reportable to the IRS on an information return and therefore not sus-

of metal to Dealer X), is not reportable to the IRS on an information return and therefore not sus- ceptible to detection, indicating a likelihood of noncompliance with the tax laws. In addition, investigations of known taxpayers in the group show a very high degree of underreporting. It is necessary for the IRS to gather statistical data from identiﬁed group members to meet the reason- able basis test because the common ﬁnancial transaction, while not susceptible to detection, is not

investigations of known taxpayers in the group show a very high degree of underreporting. It is necessary for the IRS to gather statistical data from identiﬁed group members to meet the able basis test because the common ﬁnancial transaction, while not susceptible to detection, is contrary to any IRS announced positions. ), Ascertainable Group or Class of Persons: The IRS seeks the US District Court’s authorization to serve a John Doe summons on ABC University to obtain the names of persons who made in-kind contributions to the University from January
through December
The common ﬁnancial transaction is the donation of in-kind gifts to ABC University. Investigations of known taxpayers who had made this type of gift to the University showed that
out of
taxpayers had overvalued their gifts.

A John Doe summons would be appropriate. The group’s common ﬁnancial transaction is not contrary to any IRS announced positions, nor does it suggest that the group members were in any way noncompliant with the internal revenue laws. Therefore, the statistical data gathered from the identiﬁed members of the group showing a very high degree of noncompliance is necessary to meet the “reasonable basis” requirement.
Continuation of scenario in Example
in IRM

), Ascertainable Group or Class of Persons: The IRS seeks the US District Court’s authorization to serve a John Doe summons on Bank XY of Pine County to obtain the names of those taxpayers that transferred funds to the Bank of ABC Islands for the period of January
through December

The IRS learned from an offshore voluntary disclosure initiative that several U.S. taxpayers with ownership and/or control of foreign ﬁnancial accounts at Bank of ABC Islands failed to report interest and other income earned on their accounts with this bank on their original returns. From interviewing these known customers of Bank of ABC Islands, the IRS learned that bank employees told these customers the bank would not be reporting any income from or the existence of their foreign accounts to the IRS. Controlling a foreign ﬁnancial account is not contrary to IRS announced positions, but a John Doe summons is appropriate because tax avoidance is frequently the purpose for the use of offshore accounts in a tax haven country. Also, the IRS is aware of tax compliance problems with known U.S. customers of Bank of ABC Islands. This bank’s employees apparently encouraged non- compliance. The information and identities sought from summoned records are not readily attainable from other sources, but are attainable from Bank XY of Pine County.
Continuation of scenario in Example
in IRM

), Ascertainable Group or Class of Persons: The IRS seeks US District Court authorization to serve a John Doe summons on the XYZ Barter Exchange to obtain the names and transaction records of all members of the exchange for the period of January
through December

Members of XYZ Barter Exchange engage in income producing activities that are not susceptible to detection and a likeli- hood of noncompliance with the tax laws exists. In addition, the IRS has conducted investigations of other barter exchanges, and these investigations reveal that approximately
per cent of those examined underreported their income. A John Doe summons would be appropriate.

The IRS wishes to use a John Doe summons to obtain the names and social security numbers of all members of a trade association which it believes includes non-ﬁling members. There is no ﬁnancial transaction or activity related to compliance with the tax laws that is common to members of the group. However, the IRS has statistical data from investigations of known taxpayers in the group which shows that six percent of the group has failed to ﬁle income tax returns, which per- centage is about the same as the national non-ﬁling rate.

From interviewing these known customers of Bank of ABC Islands, the IRS learned that bank employees told these customers the bank would not be reporting any income from or the existence of their foreign accounts to the IRS.

Continuation of scenario in Example 5 in IRM 25.5.7.4.1(2) 5), Ascertainable Group or Class of Persons: The IRS seeks US District Court authorization to serve a John Doe summons on the XYZ Barter Exchange to obtain the names and transaction records of all members of the exchange for the period of January 1, 2017 through December 31, 2018. Members of XYZ Barter Exchange engage in income producing activities that are not susceptible to detection and a likeli- hood of noncompliance with the tax laws exists. In addition, the IRS has conducted investigations of other barter exchanges, and these investigations reveal that approximately 75 per cent of those examined underreported their income. A John Doe summons would be appropriate. The IRS wishes to use a John Doe summons to obtain the names and social security numbers of all members of a trade association which it believes includes non-ﬁling members. There is no ﬁnancial transaction or activity related to compliance with the tax laws that is common to of the group. However, the IRS has statistical data from investigations of known taxpayers in the group which shows that six percent of the group has failed to ﬁle income tax returns, which per- centage is about the same as the national non-ﬁling rate.

Members of XYZ Barter Exchange engage in income producing activities that are not susceptible to detection and a likeli- hood of noncompliance with the tax laws exists. In addition, the IRS has conducted investigations of other barter exchanges, and these investigations reveal that approximately 75 per cent of those

IRS wishes to use a John Doe summons to obtain the names and social security numbers of members of a trade association which it believes includes non-ﬁling members. There is no transaction or activity related to compliance with the tax laws that is common to the group. However, the IRS has statistical data from investigations of known taxpayers in the which shows that six percent of the group has failed to ﬁle income tax returns, which per- is about the same as the national non-ﬁling rate.

The IRS is not entitled to use a John Doe summons to obtain names and social security numbers of the group members. Since there is no ﬁnancial activity or transaction related to compliance with the tax laws that is common to members of the group, except membership in the group, there is no reasonable basis to believe that the group as a whole has failed to ﬁle income tax returns. The statistical data of six percent is not compelling and does not indicate that the group or class of persons failed to comply with the tax laws.

The information to be obtained, including the identities of the John Does, is not readily available from other sources when the information cannot be obtained from IRS records or public sources such as telephone directories, professional directories, or reporting services, and the information cannot be obtained vol

untarily from entities such as state agencies and industry or professional organizations. The fact that it may be more difficult administratively for the IRS to conduct the investigation by relying on its own records or on public sources may not satisfy the statutory requirement. The IRS must show that retrieving the data from other sources will be impractical. This may be shown by specify
ing the additional staff hours or procedures which will be necessary, and the signiﬁcant impact on IRS normal operations if the information cannot be obtained by the summons.

The information to be obtained, including the identities of the John Does, is not readily available from other sources when the information cannot be obtained from IRS records or public sources such as telephone directories, professional directories, or reporting services, and the information cannot be obtained vol- untarily from entities such as state agencies and industry or professional organizations. The fact that it may be more difficult administratively for the IRS to conduct the investigation by relying on its own records or on public sources may not satisfy the statutory requirement. The IRS must show that retrieving the data from other sources will be impractical. This may be shown by specify- ing the additional staff hours or procedures which will be necessary, and the signiﬁcant impact on IRS normal operations if the information cannot be obtained by the summons.
Procedures for John Doe Summonses 25.5.7

Where some, but not all, of the information is readily available from public sources, the IRS must establish that the public sources are not complete or not comprehensive, and that the summoned data is necessary to ensure a thorough investigation of all taxpayers in the group under investigation.
